reviewerName: Alejandro Roque OMI "Padre Alex Roque, OMI"
reviewText: In my adult years I have come to experience the gift that dogs are to us human beings. I've had two dogs - Lady and Bonita. Each dog is unique in character, yet both were special in her own way with me and my family. To see these dogs caring for humans as service animals and seeing the difference each dog made in these people lives is truly an inspiring testimony!Thank You, PBS, for making this known.

reviewText: This was a touching look at the adoption process of Assistance Dogs.  I would like to see more about the training process, and follow ups of how the dogs adjusted into real life situations. It seems like the only follow ups they spent time on were the negative situations.

reviewText: Beautiful, it's just astonishing what dogs are and how they feel and think like us. I would love to have one dog but I think these people definitely deserve to have one 'cause they need it :).This video shows you how much a dog can help a human's life and can change it for good ^_^, great video deserves 5 stars.Think twice when you say dogs don't have feelings. They're truly Man's best friend ;).

reviewText: "Through a Dog's Eyes" is a must see for everyone.  The whole "selection" process of placing a dog with a client is amazing to watch.  It will make you smile, laugh and cry; all at the same time!This is a remarkable way to give credit to those who dedicate themselves to raising and placing these canine assistants.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I realize by not giving a "glowing review" to any depiction of any human affliction is risky and will most likely invoke the emotional wrath of those that are emotionally caught up in the subject matter, the title and described subject matter for this documentary is poorly realized. While the actual subject matter of this Documentary is inspiring on an emotional level, the subject matter is poorly indicative of the subject title and falsely lures the prospective viewer.This documentary, while emotionally charging, gave very little reflection of the "human-canine bond" and even less of a reflection, (other than very subjective, human inflections) of the view through a dog's eyes as the title implies. The reflection here is, from the people of Canine Assistants Training School.  This is not so much of a critique of their heart-felt intentions, which could be described as misguided, but more of a criticism of the title and implied subject matter.  Had the title and description been more reflective of the school and or the schools intent, this review wouldn't exist.I so had hoped for a "Documentary that explores the human-canine bond" as the title and description would have one appreciate but ended up seeing reflections from the `Canine Assistants Training School' along with their subjective interpretations and emotional charging.
Title: N/A

reviewText: What is not to love about a good dog? This video is restricted to a particular business that breeds and trains Service dogs, and the process of matching the correct dog with the individual, or should I say the correct individual with the dog.I was thinking at first that this video might be about various kinds of dogs, but as it is all about service dogs, there are just a few breeds which perform best in this capacity, so this is what we see in this video.If you or someone in your family is considering obtaining a Service Dog, I would highly recommend this video to you. If you are interested in training your pooch, there is some good advice in here about that too, though the video is not geared toward that.

reviewText: I bought this for my mom and she loved it!  She ended up sharing it with some of the women she works with (she is an aide in a special needs room) and they have all really enjoyed the stories.

reviewText: If your an animal lover especially dogs you will enjoy this documentary on the training of service dogs and how they assist their owners
Title: N/A

reviewText: Canine Assistants is an organization based in Georgia. They match disabled individuals with a Service Dog to help mitigate the disability. This video follows a group of recipients during and after a "training camp." The recipients range from small children to adults.What is so right about this video is that it shows the ups and downs of owning a SD. Many people think that it must be easy and fun to have a SD, and this video shows that that is not always the case. Some of the match-ups are wonderful, and others don't work out. In each case Canine Assistants is there to help their recipients and dogs find the best possible resolution.This is a great video, and it is appealing to all audiences, whether you are disabled or not.
summary: Amazing organization, great video!!! A must see...

reviewText: This was a good documentary and I enjoyed watching it.  However, I was expecting something "from the dog's perspective" (being aware you can't actually ask a dog what it's feeling), how it gets trained, gets used to its equipment and possibly emotional circumstances it will face with its new owner. Instead it was about how the new owners "get trained" with their new dog and how THEY feel, how THEY see the whole experience.  I was hoping "Through a Dog's Eyes" really was just that - but again, it was worth watching.
